articles.headline: Meta Profit Is Up 16% to $7.8 Billion in Recent Quarter
articles.snippet: Wall Street investors were hoping the social media giant would regain its footing after more than a year of problems, including slumping ad sales.
articles.abstract: Wall Street investors were hoping the social media giant would regain its footing after more than a year of problems, including slumping ad sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before it was called Meta, Facebook was a Wall Street darling because of its breakneck growth and big profits. But the company had lost its luster with investors over the past 18 months thanks to a slump in ad sales and what some saw as self-inflicted wounds.

articles.headline: An American Energy Giant Sees Israel as a Springboard to Europe
articles.snippet: Chevron finds itself with an abundance of natural gas on Europe’s doorstep. Amid competing regional interests, the question is how to develop it.
articles.abstract: Chevron finds itself with an abundance of natural gas on Europe’s doorstep. Amid competing regional interests, the question is how to develop it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six miles off the coast of Israel, beyond the brightly colored sails of wind surfers, an ungainly steel structure looms above the blue Mediterranean.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Ofir Berman

articles.headline: Amid Shared Pain Over Synagogue Massacre, Divisions on Death Penalty
articles.snippet: Since the 2018 attack that left 11 people dead, Jews in Pittsburgh have weighed whether the government should seek the execution of the killer.
articles.abstract: Since the 2018 attack that left 11 people dead, Jews in Pittsburgh have weighed whether the government should seek the execution of the killer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after 11 people were murdered in the Pittsburgh synagogue where he worshiped, Stephen Cohen wrote a letter to the U.S. attorney general. The Justice Department had not yet declared its intent to seek a death sentence in the case, and Mr. Cohen, the co-president of New Light, one of the three congregations that met in the Tree of Life synagogue, wanted to weigh in.

articles.headline: Jobs Sit Empty in the Public Sector, So Unions Pitch In to Recruit
articles.snippet: Shortages of state and city personnel, especially those who must work on site, are so dire that unions are helping to get people in the door.
articles.abstract: Shortages of state and city personnel, especially those who must work on site, are so dire that unions are helping to get people in the door.
articles.lead_paragraph: The State of Minnesota, like nearly every public-sector employer across the country, is in a hiring crunch.

articles.headline: How Supreme Court Justices Make Millions From Book Deals
articles.snippet: The deals have become highly lucrative for the justices, including for those who used court staff members to help research and promote their books.
articles.abstract: The deals have become highly lucrative for the justices, including for those who used court staff members to help research and promote their books.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only three months into Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson’s first Supreme Court term, she announced a book deal negotiated by the same powerhouse lawyer who represented the Obamas and James Patterson.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder, Abbie VanSickle and Elizabeth A. Harris

articles.headline: Researchers Poke Holes in Safety Controls of ChatGPT and Other Chatbots
articles.snippet: A new report indicates that the guardrails for widely used chatbots can be thwarted, leading to an increasingly unpredictable environment for the technology.
articles.abstract: A new report indicates that the guardrails for widely used chatbots can be thwarted, leading to an increasingly unpredictable environment for the technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: When artificial intelligence companies build online chatbots, like ChatGPT, Claude and Google Bard, they spend months adding guardrails that are supposed to prevent their systems from generating hate speech, disinformation and other toxic material.

articles.headline: What Happened When 15 of Twitter’s Top Celebrities Joined Threads
articles.snippet: We examined the daily activity of Ellen DeGeneres, Wiz Khalifa, Selena Gomez and others among Twitter’s most-followed to deduce if Threads has staying power.
articles.abstract: We examined the daily activity of Ellen DeGeneres, Wiz Khalifa, Selena Gomez and others among Twitter’s most-followed to deduce if Threads has staying power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Threads, the new social app from Meta, had a fast start this month when it racked up 100 million downloads in less than a week. With so much momentum, the app seemed well on its way to dethroning Twitter.

articles.headline: Elon Musk’s Quixotic Quest to Turn X Into an ‘Everything App’
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk, the owner of Twitter, is the latest Silicon Valley mogul to pursue an all-in-one app, the kind that has thrived in Asia but not elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk, the owner of Twitter, is the latest Silicon Valley mogul to pursue an all-in-one app, the kind that has thrived in Asia but not elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, a billionaire tech executive leading one of the world’s pre-eminent social platforms laid out a vision to transform it into an app that could do it all. In an online manifesto, he wrote that the app would not only be central to written communications but have audio, video, payments, commerce and more.
